paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses various TTR variants, particularly focusing on A108V and its implications for stability and amyloidosis.

patients.demographics: Portuguese subject, no specific age or sex mentioned
patients.phenotype: No evident symptoms associated with TTR amyloidosis

individual_records.phenotype_details: No evident symptoms associated with TTR amyloidosis
individual_records.evidence_sentence: Despite the subject did not exhibit any evident symptom that could be associated with TTR amyloidosis.

functional_data.summary: The A108V variant is more stable than WT TTR, with a higher percentage of tetramer observed.

variants.segregation_data: Not applicable as only one subject is reported.
variants.additional_notes: The A108V variant is suggested to be non-pathogenic and stabilizing.
key_quotes: This variant is more stable than wild type TTR both in vitro and in human plasma.
The results evidenced that in the TTR A108V heterozygote carrier there was a higher percentage of tetramer over total TTR (75.8 ± 6.8% tetramer) than in WT control plasma (69.4 ± 8.3% tetramer).

functional_data.summary: The A108I variant is predicted to be more stable than A108V.

variants.additional_notes: The A108I variant is engineered and shows potential for increased stability.
key_quotes: The modelled TTR A108I variant was predicted to be more stable than A108V by FoldX.

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data extracted from the main text.
